Also would have rathered a third button for the pour over function instead of having to double tap the iced coffee button.

Product Title: De'Longhi 3-in-1 Specialty Coffee Brewer, IcedCoffee Maker (Bold Cold Brew), Gourmet Pour Over, Premium Drip, SCA GoldenCup Certified, Glass Carafe, 8-Cup, ICM17270
Review Description: I spend about a third to half of my year living and working in Vietnam.  Coffee is a favorite there, and they have a fantastic variety of coffee beans and terroirs for bean growing, which, combined with different roasts, makes for a huge variety of coffee.  Most Vietnamese do not drink hot coffee, but instead drink iced coffee (cà phê đá) where hot coffee is poured into a glass of ice.  Whether this led to the current popularity of cold coffee in North America I don't know, but everywhere I go around the world now, I see cold coffee (with a variety of names and preparation methods).You can make cold coffee yourself, of course, by taking a regular cup of coffee from a machine and pouring it over ice, but it's not quite the same as a cold-brewed coffee taste.  This De'Longhi Specialty Coffee Brewer looks a lot like the traditional drip coffee makers I remember as a kid, because it is!  There's a glass carafe which fits into a base plate under a coffee drip filter.  Ground coffee is put into the filter, and water added to soak through the ground beans, picking up coffee flavour along the way, then nestling in the carafe.  You can make normal hot coffee this way, but for a change, add ice cubes to the carafe and let the hot coffee cool down in the carafe, then taste. The trick is to not water down the coffee with a slow, continual drip system, but to release the water as a bulk liquid into the coffee grounds first (a specially-designed "showerhead" helps with this), then into the ice en masse, preserving the concentration of the coffee but letting it cool down rapidly.  The taste is quite different from simply dripping the brewed coffee over ice, which tends to water the coffee down and make for a weak taste.  Cleaning is a bit time-consuming, but everything cleans up nicely in a couple of minutes in the sink (when cooled down).If all you want is a hot cup of coffee, or coffee served over ice cubes in a glass, then you can use any drip maker. De'Longhi says this machine is more designed around the cold-coffee brew process, although for the most part it's identical to any other drip coffee maker to my eyes.  The difference here is the showerhead that releases water faster over the ground coffee, and hence more as a dump of hot coffee on the ice (if you're making cold coffee).  For regular hot coffee, this machine is great, although a bit more expensive than many competing drip coffee machines.  The twist for cold coffee is more a marketing thing: there's nothing specific about this machine for making cold coffee than any other (except the speed at which the water is released to the coffee ground).  So, if you want to try cold coffee, then this machine is probably better than the slower drip makers, although I did not do a side-by-side comparison.  I think of this machine as a fine drip coffee maker, with the ability to make a nice cold coffee as well.  For those who've tried and liked cold coffee, this machine will deliver.

Product Title: De'Longhi 3-in-1 Specialty Coffee Brewer, IcedCoffee Maker (Bold Cold Brew), Gourmet Pour Over, Premium Drip, SCA GoldenCup Certified, Glass Carafe, 8-Cup, ICM17270
Review Description: It seems like a slightly slow method of making coffee for an automatic coffee machine.  Even on a cycle immediately following another when the machine should already be good and warmed up an 8 cup cycle takes nearly 13 minutes.  So, pour over coffee is basically making coffee the same way as most automatic coffee makers do - by pouring hot water over coffee grounds, through a filter and into a carafe/cup.  I find it a little bit funny that the machine is advertised as making pour over coffee, but truth be told, it makes the coffee just like every other automatic coffee maker - just mostly in a novel shape.  I'm not saying this is bad really, this design is better for a number of reasons... it avoids water pumps as the boiled coffee is all on top of the machine and just falls down through the grounds through gravity whereas most coffee makers boil the coffee somewhere below the shower head and pump it up through internal tubing.  That tubing is usually one of the first things to go, either getting clogged with scale or causing a leak.  The heating element is right under the water in this machine, it boils the water in the big visible reservoir (which is cool to watch, of course) and then it allows it to fall over the grinds which are actually suspended in the carafe.  Over all, I find you get coffee out of the machine that is no different than a drip brewer of equivalent general quality - but the process is novel and entertaining to watch, and I believe, should be more reliable and easier to clean over time.  So, while I do think it's a bit of a "gimmick" there are some real life benefits unrelated to your actual cup of coffee that make this worth considering anyway.The hardware itself seems relatively well made, though it is mostly plastic it still manages to look rather sharp on the counter and for the most part doesn't look like a cheap plastic appliance.  I noticed that during the brew cycles, for whatever reason, only 2 or three of the total of 6 holes that the hot water comes out of to "pour over" the grounds actually has any reasonable amount of water flowing out of it, this doesn't really seem right to me.  The machine at several points during brew cycles makes rather loud and startling "pop" noises.  I have to admit, it made me jump more than once and this really wasn't a very endearing property of the machine.  The carafe is a lot bigger than you would normally expect for a brewer that only makes 8 cups maximum, but it's because it has to accommodate the coffee grinds/filter inside the carafe.As usual, I find the "over ice" coffee a bit more hype than anything.  It's difficult to use with anything but a full 8 cup cycle because you have to measure out the amount of ice into the carafe as well as the water, separately, and is difficult to do because the markings especially for ice are not exactly precise and it only gives you the "max" markings for it.  I did make an attempt at the over ice setting, attempting to make only 4 cups instead of 8 by aiming for the half way points to the respecting "max" lines.  It turned out okay, the coffee isn't watered down but it does seem too bitter to me (I suppose it keeps it steeping in the grounds longer before opening the valve to let it drop into the carafe) as promised.  Still I can't see myself using it this way much in the future.In summary.  The machine looks nice despite being mostly plastic.  I don't feel like it produces better or worse coffee than a good traditional drip brewer, but the process is more fun to watch.  I feel like this method will likely result in an easier to maintain and longer lasting coffee maker.  Slightly less convenient than some other "normal" brewers, but not so much so that I would actually list it as a true negative.
